title.narrative: Western Indian Ocean Marine Science Association (WIOMSA) 2012-2017
Western Indian Ocean Marine Science Association (WIOMSA) 2012-2017

description.narrative: Syftet med fortsatt stöd till WIOMSA är att inom det marina området stödja organisatorisk hållbarhet, främja institutionell multidisciplinär forskningskapacitet och tekniköverföring, att stärka befintliga och nya partnerskap samt att främja resultatspridning. Såsom ett regionalt forskningsråd kommer WIOMSA verka för en övergång från stöd av enskilda kunskaps- genererande projekt till institutione

The objective of the continued support to the Western Indian Ocean Marine Science Association (WIOMSA) is to support organisational sustainability, conduct multi-disciplinary/trans-disciplinary and participatory quality research, to strengthen existing and new partnership, to develop and implement an effective communication strategy. As a regional research council, a move from support to indi

To establish a common regional platform by 2017 to advance and apply science for the sustainable development of marine and coastal environments, bringing together governments, institutions, the private sector and community stakeholders for joint actions, and ensuring that a financially sustainable WIOMSA plays a key role in this process.

WIOMSA/Western Indian Ocean Marine Science Association

policy-marker.narrative: Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Convention on Biological Diversity
Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Convention to Combat Desertification
Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Framework Convention on Climate Change - Adaptation
Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Framework Convention on Climate Change - Mitigation
Reproductive, Maternal, Newborn and Child Health (RMNCH)

description.narrative: * WIOMSA has continued to support research on marine and coastal areas through the MASMA Programme, projects on management of Marine Protected Area; small-scale fisheries; climate change adaptation at local level; assesment and mitigation of bycatch of large, non-target vulnerable megafauna species; distribution, status, threats and management of dugongs as well as identification and assessment of upwelling areas and a socio-ecological assessemnt of fisheries in estuarine systems. Furthermore, the requirement to engage local, national or regional organisations as part of the effort to ensure practical relevance and uptake of the research results was introduced, as well as a "proof of concept" - research results that will demonstrate the feasibility of behavioural, social and/or environmenal impact. * On the regional level, WIOMSA has strengthened its efforts in closing the gap between science and policy in the region and contributed to policy and management processes in the region, such as support to Marine Protected Areas capacity development as well as policy decisions at a regional level in partnership with UNEP/Nairobi Convention. Also in cooperation with the Nairobi Convention, the establishment of Science-to-Policy meetings as input to COP meetings of the Convention. WIOMSA also published the first ever "Regional State of the Coast Report for the Western Indian Ocean", based on the format and structure of the UN-coordinated World Oceans Assessment. * On the global level, WIOMSA participated in the UN World Ocean Conferance in New York in June 2017, submitted 3 "Voluntary Commitments" and organised 2 side events. * Furthermore, several strategic steps were undertaken to ensure gender features in research and WIOMSA in general. The supported research projects were required to make explicit important gender dimensions of the research and to provide training opportunities to strengthen the role of female researchers. A WIOMSA Gender Policy was approved in 2017, to ensure that WIOMSA´s core activities and programmes benefit both genders equally and have the same opportunity to participate and contribute at all levels in the organisation. Finally, also in 2017, a "Women in Marine Science Network" was launched, to provide women in marine sciences with a platform to share experiences, challenges and solutions and promote their visibility within and outside the Western Indian Ocean region. * Capacity building activities included grants for students for shorter research training, for participation in conferences etc - in total 221 grants out of which 44% to female students, and grants through which MSc and PhD students were involved in long-term supported research projects - in total 16 MSc- and 10 PhD-students. Also, in total more than 1200 individuals from all the WIOMSA countries, with the exception of Somalia, benefitted from different capacity development activities. * As from end-2017, a Sida-supported "Biträdande Bilateral Expert" has been placed at WIOMSA Secretariat, working as a "Climate Change Coordinator". * During the agreement period, the financial sustainability of the organisation has been strengthened. In 2012, a "WIOMSA Trust Fund" was registered to in the long-run provide funding to cover costs for the running of the WIOMSA Secreatariat, and increased income over the years from providing technical services to other parties, arrangements of workshops and symposia, sale of books and publications, membership fees etc have resulted in in 37% of core costs at WIOMSA to be covered by non-Sida funds. * During the years 2012-17, in total 7 numbers of the "Western Indian Ocean Journal of Marine Science" were published, in addition a special issue on coral reefs of Mauritius. 16 books, 2 policy briefs, 16 papers from WIOMSA supported projects in peer-reviewed journals, 2 pubilcations in popular fora and 2 videos produced.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
